title: Across the Andes: Riding the 1,517km Rat Race Trans Andean

Across the Andes: Riding the 1,517km Rat Race Trans Andean

We gather on the beach before dawn for a ceremonial dipping of our rear wheels into the Pacific Ocean. The plan is to cross the continent of South America, riding due east from the coast of Chile to the coast of Argentina, taking in the mountains of the Andes and the vast plains of the Pampas along the way. Understandably, the atmosphere in the hotel last night was one of nervous excitement.

Everyone here is part of the Rat Race Trans Andean event, a nine-day, 1,517km ride that isn’t a race but is instead billed as an ‘extraordinary global adventure for everyday people’. Certainly, it’s a diverse group of 29 riders on the start line, ranging from Marie-Louise, a racing cyclist from England in her twenties, to Scott and Charleen, a couple in their sixties from Tucson, Arizona. Our number includes lawyers and IT specialists, engineers and construction workers, even a former professional footballer and a violinist.

Hardly anyone has experience of multiday adventure riding, and we all spent the previous evening packing, unpacking and repacking our bikes as we tried to work out the best combination of kit for a journey that none of us can really anticipate. Is it true that anyone reasonably fit can cross South America with the right support? We’re about to find out.

Day one: into the mountains

The start is in the coastal resort of Concón, near Valparaíso in Chile. Ahead of us today lies 170km and a vertical mile of climbing to a mountain hostel. After some final words from head of expeditions Abbi Naylor, we’re off. I join up with two old university friends, Gary and Rich, and we soon find ourselves riding with Marie-Louise and her cat 1 race team colleague Laura.

The five of us work well together, riding smoothly and pointing out hazards in the road. Soon we learn to point out only the really big hazards, because it will prove to be a long journey if we have to shout ‘hole!’ every few seconds. Instead, we settle into a rhythm of riding and chatting that makes time fly.

Up ahead we can see the jagged silhouette of the Andes as we follow the Aconcagua River upstream on good tarmac, passing maize and avocado farms, apple and cherry orchards, and vineyards at the far north of Chile’s Central Valley wine region. To get us on quieter roads, Abbi has devised a route that includes a river crossing only manageable by off-road vehicles or people willing to shoulder their bikes and pick their way along old tree trunks lashed together by local villagers. Remarkably, we all emerge dry on the other side.

By midday the temperature is in the 30s. The Trans Andean aid stations every 40km (three vans leapfrog each other throughout each day) provide a welcome chance to eat – energy bars, fruit, wraps with hummus, avocado and ham – top up water bottles and slap on more suncream.

In the afternoon sun, with little shade and some steep ramps, the final haul to the day’s finish is hot work. A few riders climb into the broom wagon, a bus driven at the back by Rat Race founder Jim Mee, for a lift to the hostel where we spend the night. That’s very much part of the inclusive ethos: you can climb into the van if you need to, and carry on riding later, but most are determined to get to Buenos Aires on pedal power alone.

Day two: ever upwards

It’s uphill from the first pedal stroke on day two as we ride towards the lunar landscape of the rarely travelled Chilean side of Uspallata Pass at an altitude of 3,850m. The forces of Latin American liberator José de San Martín crossed here (in the opposite direction) in 1817 to free Chile from colonial rule, surprising the Spanish authorities who never believed anyone could navigate such terrain with 10,000 horses, 5,000 men and heavy artillery. Only around half made it to the other side.

Towering cliffs loom over us, funnelling a powerful headwind down the valley into our faces. The wind adds an extra obstacle that is tough psychologically. The five of us soon pick up Jesper, a former professional footballer from Denmark whose calves are thicker than many people’s thighs. We settle into a chaingang, but there’s little respite from the headwind. I’m grateful to get to the next aid station and decide to ride the following section at my own pace to soak up the otherworldly view.

The 29 hairpins of the Caracoles (snails in Spanish) climb rival anything I’ve ridden in the Alps. The glacier that carved this high valley has long since disappeared but it left behind the terminal moraine into which this looping line of tarmac is cut. As I climb, the crucible of rock faces in crimson, orange and black slowly gives way to a cloudless sky, and I catch sight of snow-capped peaks in the distance. Watching us from the surrounding hillsides are wild guanacos, close relatives of the domesticated llama.

So far we’ve shared today’s road with the occasional truck, but soon they turn off for the 3km tunnel through to Argentina, while we turn right onto the gravel track that will carry us up and over the pass. We’re already above 3,000m but we still have around 700m of vertical ascent before we reach the top. While the surface is mostly hard-packed, the switchbacks are littered with rocks the size of fists, so the climb needs our full attention.

At last, the statue of Christ the Redeemer of the Andes comes into view, marking the border with Argentina and the top of the climb. Today is the shortest day at around 75km (the average is 168km) but the climbing and altitude make it one of the toughest. In the thin air, I stop to appreciate the snowy bulk of Aconcagua, South America’s highest peak, to the north. The view is breathtaking, literally.

Days three to nine: all downhill from here

After a night in the only hostel left in Los Penitentes, once a thriving ski resort but shuttered by a combination of Covid and climate change, we strike out for the wine-making centre of Mendoza, home of Malbec.

The next 150km along the Mendoza River valley is probably the most beautiful road I’ve ever ridden. At daybreak we’re hemmed in by towering cliffs that block out the sun, but the view soon opens out into a wide valley the scale of which is beyond anything I’ve seen outside the Canadian Rockies. A ribbon of perfect tarmac threads down the entire length and we barely have to pedal to hit 60kmh.

After a night in the laidback city of Mendoza (and a memorable inch-thick ribeye steak) we enter the vast Pampas grasslands that make up much of Argentina and join the Ruta 7 highway that will take us the remaining 900km to the finish in Buenos Aires.

‘It’s about endurance now,’ Abbi warns. ‘We’re crossing a continent. It’s not supposed to be easy.’

With Argentina in the grip of a heatwave and temperatures rising into the 40s, there is little danger of that. The aid stations are a lifesaver. Indefatigable fitness trainer Jill and the other support crew keep up a constant flow of encouragement, savoury wraps, cola, electrolytes, melon, salted oranges and, most importantly, ice.

We stuff pop socks with ice cubes, shove them down our backs and let the melting water drip blissfully down our spines. By this stage most people are beyond caring what they look like.

The next few days follow the same pattern: ride 200km along a highway, rest, repeat. As a rouleur-style rider I’m in my element. It’s the only time that ‘you’re so sturdy’ can be taken as a compliment.

It’s hot and the days are long, but I’m not complaining. All we have to worry about is eating, drinking, pushing the pedals and watching the Argentine countryside pass by. Before we know it, we’re rolling our bikes down to Balendra beach at the mouth of the River Plate to dip our wheels in the water again and mark the end of the ride. Then we wade out into the river to wash away nine days of salt and sweat.

Can any reasonably fit cyclist cross a continent? Absolutely.

The details

Cross a continent

What: Trans Andean Coast to Coast
Where: Valparaíso, Chile, to Buenos Aires, Argentina
How far: 1,517km over nine days (average 168km per day)
Elevation: 8,592m
Next one: 31st Jan-11 Feb 2024
Price: US$4,750 (approx £3,785)
